description.narrative:
East Africa Grain Council (EAGC) a regional membership organization has experience in creating market linkages for small holder farmers. EAGC represents those engaged in Grain such as Producers, Processors, transporters , traders among others . EAGC covers trading in all cereals such as maize, wheat, rice, barley, sorghum, and millet. In this project EAGC will lead in; Online registration offarmers and creation of a centralized database of digital identities/profiles for farmers, Use of EAGC#s RATIN SMS facility to disseminate customized and specific messages to the registered farmers and agriculture extension staff, Linking banks with farmers# database to facilitate faster processing of loans and for payment settlements, Work ng with the selected farmers# organizations to keep track of their costs of production and gross margins to help farmers track the expenses incurred in producing grain commodities and the volume of produce to analyze the cost of production per unit and the expected margin if they were to sell at prevailing market price and finally Link ng farmers to available markets by sharing information on purchase orders posted on the EAGC trading platform (GSoko). This will trigger farmers# sales in response to the buyer inquiries/orders.
As a result strong producer groups will be formed with capacity to engage in the different markets and earn a profitable income from agariculture.

participating-org.narrative: EAGC was founded in 2005 and registered in December 2006 as a regional membership-based not-for-profit company limited by guaranteerepresenting stakeholders in the grain value chain in Eastern and Southern Africa. The membership of EAGC comprises of; Active members# those directly dealing in handling grains including Grain producers, Grain Traders and Grain Processors/Millers; Affiliate members # regional and national business associations for the farmers, traders or processors who affiliate as an organization and Associate members# service providers to the grain sector including inputs, financial institutions and international organizations with an interest in the grain sector. EAGC#s goal is to promote an efficient, inclusive and structured grain trading system to increase national and cross border trade in grains leading to increased incomes of the poor men, women and youth leading to poverty reduction andimproved food security. The goal directly aligns to the United Nations Social Development Goals (SDG) on #No poverty, Zero hunger# and the cross cutting goals of gender equality, climate action and partnerships to achieve the goals. The establishment of EAGC was to deal with four key sector challenges such as; Ensuring adequate availability of grain commodities in the Eastern Africa region, The need to enhance accessibility of grain markets, Unpredictable, disruptive and politically motivated policies that curtails accessto markets and limited incentives in the existing market systems and Limited access to quality grain inputs, insufficient infrastructure to control post-harvest losses as well as limited access to value addition. To resolve the mentioned challenges, EAGC is mandated to develop and promote structured grain trading systems in the Eastern Africa region through its four key functions namely; structuring grain trade systems, provision of market information, policy and advocacy work as well as capacity building. The gender aspects run through all levels of interventions from farmer groups# recruitment and profiling, training, warehouse certification, support with post-harvest handling equipment with a target to achieve a minimum of 30% of either gender. EAGC interventions have therefore impacted both men and women. EAGC works in ten (10) countries across the region namely Rwanda, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, DRC, Malawi and Zambia.
